questions.question: What does optogenetics involve?
questions.answerChoiceB: Introducing genes for light-responsive ion channels
questions.answerChoiceC: Using magnetic fields to activate neurons
questions.answerChoiceD: Applying electrical currents to specific brain regions
questions.answerChoiceE: Observing natural neuron activity without intervention

questions.question: What is the primary use of Transcranial Magnetic Stimulation (TMS) in research?
questions.answerChoiceB: For creating long-term changes in brain activity
questions.answerChoiceC: To confirm findings from brain activity studies
questions.answerChoiceD: As a standard treatment for neurological disorders

questions.question: Who invented the electroencephalogram (EEG) and what does it measure?
questions.answerChoiceC: Ivan Pavlov; brain's response to stimuli
questions.answerChoiceE: John Watson; behavioral responses in the brain

questions.question: What is the N170 peak in EEG studies?
questions.answerChoiceC: A peak in response to visual images of faces
questions.answerChoiceE: A measure of general brain arousal

questions.question: What does a brain-machine interface (BMI) allow a person to do?
Which early theory of brain localization was later discredited?
What is the term for electrical changes in the brain after a stimulus, recorded with EEG?
What does computational neuroscience use to understand nervous system functions?
What is a key characteristic of artificial neural networks?
questions.answerChoiceA: They are based on historical psychiatric practices
questions.answerChoiceB: They use computational models to mimic brain neuron networks
questions.answerChoiceC: They rely solely on EEG data
questions.answerChoiceD: They are used primarily for surgical procedures
questions.answerChoiceE: They function without any machine learning algorithms

questions.question: What triggers the start of an action potential in neurons?
questions.answerChoiceB: A rise in membrane potential to the threshold

questions.question: What happens when voltage-gated sodium channels open at the threshold?
questions.answerChoiceD: Sodium ions rapidly enter the cell

questions.question: What occurs when voltage-gated potassium channels fully open?
questions.answerChoiceC: Potassium ions leave the cell, hyperpolarizing it

questions.question: What is the 'relative refractory period' in neuronal action potential?
questions.answerChoiceA: When the neuron cannot fire another action potential
questions.answerChoiceB: When more stimulus is required to reach the threshold
questions.answerChoiceE: When calcium channels open in the axon terminal

questions.question: Where is the action potential first initiated in a neuron?
What is 'saltatory conduction' in myelinated neurons?
questions.answerChoiceA: Action potential jumps from node to node

questions.question: What happens at the axon terminal when an action potential arrives?
How are neurotransmitters transported to the axon terminal?
questions.answerChoiceE: By direct synthesis in the axon terminal

questions.question: What happens when neurotransmitters bind to postsynaptic receptors?
questions.answerChoiceC: Change in the receptor's structure and function
questions.answerChoiceD: Action potential in the postsynaptic neuron
questions.answerChoiceE: Calcium ions enter the postsynaptic cell

questions.question: How do metabotropic receptors differ from ionotropic receptors?
questions.answerChoiceA: They do not change membrane potential
questions.answerChoiceB: They are not themselves ion channels
questions.answerChoiceC: They only respond to voltage changes
questions.answerChoiceE: They are not involved in neurotransmission

questions.question: What was a significant achievement of deep neural networks in the field of AI?
questions.answerChoiceB: Beating a professional player at Go

questions.question: What is the goal of computational psychiatry?
questions.answerChoiceA: To use AI for surgical procedures
questions.answerChoiceB: To improve psychiatric treatment through algorithms

questions.question: What modern method allows scientists to temporarily perturb brain regions?
Which philosopher incorrectly believed consciousness originated in the human heart?
What is the primary function of the frontal lobe in the human brain?
Which ion channels are responsible for the passage of ions across the neuronal membrane?
What does the N170 peak in electrical activity indicate in neural processing?
What is the function of the parasympathetic nervous system?
What is the primary function of the Fusiform face area (FFA) in the brain?
What is the role of G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) in the brain?
questions.answerChoiceB: Converting extracellular signals into intracellular responses

questions.question: Which process involves the release of material from an intracellular vesicle into the extracellular space?
What is the function of the Fornix in the brain?
What is the primary role of GABA (gamma-aminobutryic acid) in the central nervous system?
What is the primary function of glia cells in the nervous system?
What is the function of ion channels in neurons?
questions.answerChoiceB: Allowing passage of ions across the cell membrane
questions.answerChoiceD: Converting chemical signals to electrical signals

questions.question: What occurs during hyperpolarization of a neuron's membrane?
questions.answerChoiceA: The membrane potential becomes more positive
questions.answerChoiceC: The membrane potential becomes more negative

questions.question: What type of memory does not require conscious effort to retrieve?
What structure in the thalamus processes auditory information?
Which of the following best describes the role of broadly tuned neurons in taste perception?
questions.answerChoiceA: They are responsible for detecting only one specific taste.
questions.answerChoiceB: They respond strongly to all kinds of food stimuli.
questions.answerChoiceC: They encode many different tastes by activating in specific patterns.
questions.answerChoiceD: They are only activated by very strong taste stimuli.
questions.answerChoiceE: They are not involved in taste perception.

questions.question: Which of the following mechanoreceptors is NOT responsible for transmitting information about touch, pressure, and vibration?
Which mechanoreceptors have small receptive fields and are sensitive to the precise location and properties of a stimulus?
What is the primary function of low-threshold thermoreceptors?
questions.answerChoiceC: To transmit information about light touch
questions.answerChoiceE: To detect low frequencies in sound

questions.question: What is the primary role of nociceptors?
questions.answerChoiceB: To detect light touch and pressure
questions.answerChoiceC: To process injurious stimuli and signal pain
questions.answerChoiceD: To encode different tastes and smells

questions.question: Which sensory information does NOT ascend to the brain via the same pathway as touch and proprioception?
What is the primary function of the corticospinal tract?
questions.answerChoiceB: To transmit sensory information to the brain
questions.answerChoiceC: To carry voluntary movement information to the spinal cord
questions.answerChoiceD: To process visual and auditory information

questions.question: What is the primary role of the rubrospinal tract in humans?
questions.answerChoiceA: To carry a large percentage of voluntary movement signals to the limbs
questions.answerChoiceC: To transmit sensory information from the limbs
questions.answerChoiceD: To process pain and temperature signals

questions.question: Which brain structure is involved in the coordination of movement?
Which pathway is responsible for flexible and adaptable motor commands?
Which of the following is not included in the somatosensation sense?
What is the primary role of the cornea in the visual system?
questions.answerChoiceD: To protect the eye from physical damage
questions.answerChoiceE: To regulate the amount of light entering the eye

questions.question: How do photoreceptors in the retina respond to light?
questions.answerChoiceB: By hyperpolarization and reduced signal transmission
questions.answerChoiceD: By converting light into sound waves
questions.answerChoiceE: By generating electrical signals directly from light

questions.question: What function do the cells of the LGN (Lateral Geniculate Nucleus) perform?
What does the ventral stream of visual processing focus on?
What are the basic tastes perceivable by humans?
questions.answerChoiceA: Sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and spicy
questions.answerChoiceB: Sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and umami
questions.answerChoiceC: Sweet, sour, umami, spicy, and astringent
questions.answerChoiceD: Sweet, sour, bitter, salty, and tangy
questions.answerChoiceE: Sweet, sour, umami, salty, and cool

questions.question: What is a common characteristic of stimuli that trigger action potentials?
questions.answerChoiceB: They increase the membrane potential to a point more positive than rest
questions.answerChoiceC: They always lead to the immediate release of neurotransmitters
questions.answerChoiceD: They are exclusively mechanical in nature
questions.answerChoiceE: They decrease the membrane potential to a point more negative than rest

questions.question: What occurs when a neuron reaches its threshold potential?
questions.answerChoiceB: The neuron enters a refractory period

questions.question: What is the behavior of voltage-gated potassium channels during an action potential?
questions.answerChoiceA: They open immediately when the potential reaches 0mV
questions.answerChoiceB: They are slow to open and close, fully opening at the peak of the action potential
questions.answerChoiceC: They remain closed throughout the action potential
questions.answerChoiceD: They open at the resting potential
questions.answerChoiceE: They open when the cell is hyperpolarized

questions.question: Where is the action potential regenerated in myelinated axons?
questions.answerChoiceC: Only at the Nodes of Ranvier

questions.question: What happens when neurotransmitters bind to their receptors on the postsynaptic cell?
questions.answerChoiceA: The postsynaptic cell is immediately depolarized
questions.answerChoiceB: It triggers the opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
questions.answerChoiceD: The receptor changes its structure, activating the postsynaptic cell
questions.answerChoiceE: The neurotransmitter is repackaged into vesicles

questions.question: What is the primary function of dendrites in a neuron?
What characterizes the axons of neurons?
questions.answerChoiceB: Vary in thickness along their length
questions.answerChoiceC: Used for transmitting electrical signals or chemical transmitters
questions.answerChoiceE: Main site for receiving synaptic inputs

questions.question: Where do axons typically begin and end in a neuron?
questions.answerChoiceA: Begin at dendrites and end in the soma
questions.answerChoiceB: Begin at the soma and end in the axon terminals
questions.answerChoiceC: Begin and end in the dendritic spines
questions.answerChoiceD: Begin and end in synaptic clefts
questions.answerChoiceE: Begin in the myelin sheath and end in Nodes of Ranvier

questions.question: What distinguishes grey matter from white matter in the central nervous system?
questions.answerChoiceA: Grey matter contains myelinated axons, white matter contains cell bodies
questions.answerChoiceB: Grey matter is primarily found inside the brain, white matter outside
questions.answerChoiceC: Grey matter contains cell bodies and dendrites, white matter contains myelinated axons
questions.answerChoiceD: Grey matter regulates motor functions, white matter sensory functions
questions.answerChoiceE: Grey matter contains glial cells, white matter contains neurons

questions.question: What is the primary role of astrocytes in the nervous system?
questions.answerChoiceD: To clear away pathogens and damaged neurons

questions.question: What is the primary function of dendrites in a neuron?
What is the main function of an axon in a neuron?
Where do axons typically begin and end in a neuron?
questions.answerChoiceA: Begin at dendrites and end in the soma
questions.answerChoiceB: Begin at the soma and end in the axon terminals
questions.answerChoiceC: Begin and end in the dendritic spines
questions.answerChoiceD: Begin and end in synaptic clefts
questions.answerChoiceE: Begin in the myelin sheath and end in Nodes of Ranvier

questions.question: What is a synapse in the context of neural communication?
questions.answerChoiceA: A part of the neuron that produces neurotransmitters
questions.answerChoiceB: The gap between two neurons across which signals are transmitted
questions.answerChoiceD: The region in the neuron where myelination begins
questions.answerChoiceE: A bundle of axons in the central nervous system

questions.question: How does the structure of a neuron relate to its function?
questions.answerChoiceA: Motor neurons have multiple long axons
questions.answerChoiceC: Motor neurons have a soma surrounded by dendrites and a long axon
questions.answerChoiceD: Interneurons have long axons and complex dendritic arbors
questions.answerChoiceE: All neurons have the same structure regardless of their function

questions.question: What is the distinction between grey matter and white matter in the central nervous system?
questions.answerChoiceA: Grey matter is made up of myelinated axons, white matter of cell bodies and dendrites
questions.answerChoiceB: Grey matter contains cell bodies and dendrites, white matter contains myelinated axons
questions.answerChoiceC: Grey matter is only found in the brain, white matter only in the spinal cord
questions.answerChoiceD: Grey matter regulates motor functions, white matter sensory functions
questions.answerChoiceE: There is no significant difference between grey and white matter

questions.question: What is the role of astrocytes in the nervous system?
questions.answerChoiceD: To regulate the chemical makeup of extracellular fluid

questions.question: What is the primary function of microglia in the brain?
questions.answerChoiceC: To act as the immune cells of the brain

questions.question: What is the primary function of the sympathetic nervous system?
questions.answerChoiceB: Increasing heart rate and blood pressure under stress

questions.question: What are the two states of membrane potentials described in neurons?
What triggers the opening of ligand-gated ion channels?
What is the primary determinant of a neuron's resting potential?
What is the all-or-none principle in the context of action potentials?
questions.answerChoiceA: Neurons fire at full strength or not at all
questions.answerChoiceB: All ion channels open simultaneously during an action potential
questions.answerChoiceC: An action potential affects all parts of the neuron equally
questions.answerChoiceD: All neurotransmitters are released at once during synaptic transmission
questions.answerChoiceE: All neurons in a network respond to a stimulus simultaneously

questions.question: What is the role of myelin in neuronal function?
questions.answerChoiceB: It speeds up action potential conduction
questions.answerChoiceC: It serves as a neurotransmitter receptor
questions.answerChoiceD: It slows down the propagation of nerve impulses

questions.question: What happens at the postsynaptic cell when neurotransmitters bind to receptors?
questions.answerChoiceB: It initiates the release of more neurotransmitters
questions.answerChoiceC: Ions flow across the membrane, changing its potential
